Southhouston was having persistant issues with Tax being incorrectly applied or ommited (along with discounts and shipping fees) to various high level customers throughout the year. Multiple times we went through support cases, tickets, and customizations to try to mitigate these, but the issues still cropped up. There were about 5 different issues that were all related to data quality and user input, but they were unable to change their process and resulted and just working out of QuickBooks. For example - there was an issue where if you leave shipping address blank the Sync engine does not honour the tax status of the customer, and will charge tax no matter what. At the end of the day - they were used to using the QB ecosystem where their data quality didnt matter and they could override the tax, shipping, and discount rates on the fly without following the rules of the sync engine. As a result - they stopped using method for creating or managing sales transactions after trying multiple times to follow best practicies - too many orders slipped through.

This makes your organization more like one that is looking to get additional revenue quickly without emphasis on customer service and relationship building. Some times it is a good thing to establish good faith and trust without charging your clients for basic things that should be offered at no charge. We are a small manufacturing company that lost work orders when moving from QuickBooks Desktop Enterprise to QuickBooks Enterprise Online. There are a lot of us. Your system adds that function, but is also a production scheduling and probably all the way to MRP II (with complete inventory tracking.... ).

While these are great, and we will likely move to a complete ERP system in the future, we are simply looking to replace that functionality today.

Your system is more than we need - and the costs associated to achieve only what we need exceed the benefit today.

As this is a significantly sized market, and a feeder for future options, perhaps you would consider an option that provides seamless work order integration, with only a product masterfile, that syncs with QuickBooks for sales and billing, without production scheduling (an add-on), inventory management (an add-on), mrp, MRP, or MRPII....

We would pay to replace our CRM (currently FreshSales) with yours, and for integrated work orders, but it would need to be reasonably priced for this market.

Good luck and best!

Tom

We worked with Method for months to try to rectify the problems, or at least get an accounting of what changes were made by Method so that we could correct it. 1. They have QB hosted on a server and the method Sync engine as well. For the real-time sync, we have to have the QB open and connected to Method.
2. Their workflow is they have different users going to Single User mode frequently in QBs on their individual side (desktop). So, as we know when any user goes to Single User, other users have to log out.
3. This results in the user currently signed into QB on the server exiting forcefully and thus the sync engine is disconnected.
4. We asked them to install it on a dedicated system where one is working actively at all times and can use it as the Main sync engine. But the conflict is, going to Single User logs out every other user and eventually, it will disconnect sync at that moment.

Arnab signed up in November 2024 and began a Dedicated Enhancement Plan in January 2025 with the goal of capturing customer sales data through a custom dashboard. Due to internal delays, work did not begin until late January. While progress was made over several months, the project moved slowly and key recommendations, such as adding more hours to accelerate work, were rejected.

By May, Arnab began testing the solution but grew frustrated with the pace and the limitations of the stock reporting UI, which he felt should not require paid customization. He temporarily canceled, reinstated after leadership discussions, and then raised concerns again in June about app tile issues and billing.

Despite progress shown in a June 5 meeting, Arnab remained unsatisfied with the reporting experience and ultimately chose to cancel his account permanently that evening.

On the good side for Method:
- LOVE that it is totally QB driven. It is clear who is and is not a customer.
- Really appreciate that it is a company with whom we had a human being as a contact. And one person. With a name. Who knew what the system did and did not do and was totally clear about it, did not fumfuh or BS.
 
On the negative side (things that are fixable):
- The interface was not totally clear to us as users. How do simply create a user-specific list of contacts, to-do’s, etc., was not clear to us.
 - The lack of a strong interface with Outlook. At least a bcc to Method would have made Method a possibility for us.
 
On the negative side (things that are beyond your control)
- Our users have used salesforce before so it was not “ugh, another new thing?!”
- Salesforce is a highly developed product so it has the outlook interface, the QB link, yada yada. I felt that we were moving to the industry standard, a more defensible decision to my team. (I view our team as my “board of directors” in this.”
 
I really wish you guys all the best and hope you keep building out a great system. It could easily be that we use it for another of our companies in the future.

just didn't use it

Their needs: 

Stage 1: Purchase Order: generally where orders come in usually here is where we have to check that their pricing from the pourchase order is correct with our current pricing. Our pricing generally changes once a year and is based on volume. If we could have some sort of pricing rules built in to reflect that, that would be great.
 
Stage 2: Invoice: Usually if there is a price change we then send a final invoice to the customer for approval.

Stage 3: Payment: some of our customers require payment up front, others we bill after the product has shipped.

Stage 4: Custom Printing: some of our products have the option for custom printing. Generally, the process of this goes:

                Customer sends us their logo

                Logo created into a proof

                Send to customer for approval

               Having steps for each of these and even a way to send the proof where they can just click accept or reject with comments, would be great.

Stage 5: Fulfillment: this is where orders are filled in our warehouse

Stage 6: Shipping:  once the order is fulfilled, we are notified it is ready to ship where we then arrange for a truck to come pick it up or if smaller use standard mail to ship it out

Stage 7: Send Bill: if the customer does not require prepayment, we would send the invoice once the product has been shipped.

Discussion:

I explained to Mike that their request would need to be scoped out, and since they had already used their 1 Free Hour, they would need to sign up for the Pay-Per-Use (PPU) service. Unfortunately, they felt that our PPU was too expensive and were unwilling to proceed with it. I clarified our processes to ensure expectations were clear, but they were still dissatisfied with the costs involved in customizing their requirements in Method.

Ah, why am I cancelling...
Customer service was very helpful, and the people very nice. However, this is the most difficult and low-functioning CRM I've ever used. The UI is bland and hard to look at all day so I tried to use it as little as possible, which does NOT work for a CRM; there are non-sensical  pathways (far-from intuitive unless you're a developer) and the need for MANY clicks to get basic things done, if you can even find the right button. Data is difficult to manage and access, the customizations are expensive and inaccessible, reports are a joke. 
Not to mention how often we had web-lead errors, and down-time with Google gadget, etc.. 
We gave it a year, and I'm sorry we waited so long to cancel and move on. We spent so much money and time customizing to get the minimal function we did. We also lost dozens of leads to technical errors. Two weeks into a new CRM and everything is clicking, managers are happy, and CRM is fully functional. For example, I built a web-to-lead form and had it up on our website in 1 hour -  by myself!! It took weeks and hundreds of dollars to get so far with Method. 
I think your new version should have been worked on MUCH longer before you released it. It seems like we paid to have you guys finish working out the bugs in it. With the loss of leads and loss of time ($1000s in our time) trying to get this to work, I wish we had charged you instead of paying you.
Respectfully, Good luck, guys.

We truly appreciate your time and effort throughout this process.

Method does an excellent job of syncing with quickbooks but that is where its effectiveness really drops off. Your business plan to drive revenue by forcing businesses to purchase customization is not friendly or fun. The whole process is frustratingly broken and the CRM is not at all good out of the box compared to other CRM's in the market place at price points far below Method. Other CRM's provide world class support and customization for free as part of the service and the emphasis is on making my job easier not in frustrating me into purchasing customizations. Method is not user friendly, it is slow, and is over priced, and ultimately even though it has perhaps the best integration with quick-books overall its usefulness is far less than other CRM's. Bottom line Method is painful to use. I have enough pain in my day without purchasing it from you guys.For examples of superior CRM's Zoho - super friendly interface and features Vtiger another great CRM for an exceptional price. Ask those guys for anything and they fix it. bi weekly updates that actually include our requests. Biggest failure for Method is the approach.  Im looking for superior support and useability at an affordable price, not roadblocks and additional fees.  Good luck with your model and product.
